results.title: Bonjour Balwyn
results.creator_credit: Nigel Buesst and Experimental Film Fund, Australia Council for the Arts
results.brief_description: A feature film about a young man’s futile attempt to publish a trendy magazine in Carlton. When his efforts begin to fail, he must turn to petty crime to help make ends meet. Stars John Duigan and Peter Cummins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nigel Buesst and Experimental Film Fund, Australia Council for the Arts

results.title: Mabo: The Life of an Island Man
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Denise Haslem and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Filmmaker Trevor Graham documented the only film record of the Mabo proceedings in 1989 in his film “Land Bilong islanders” and in the process established a friendship with Eddie Koiki Mabo. This film documents the extraordinary life of a man so passionate about his family and home that he fought an entire nation and its legal system. Sadly, he died five months before the High Court upheld his claim for “Native Title”. However he cemented a place in Australia’s history. This documentary won an AFI award in 1997.
results.title_for_label: Mabo: The Life of an Island Man
results.creator_credit_for_label: Trevor Graham, Denise Haslem and Film Australia

results.title: The Getting of Wisdom
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Phillip Adams, Australian Film Commission and Southern Cross Film Productions
results.brief_description: Laura Tweedle Ramsbotham is about to enter another world. From her home in sleepy, rural Australia she ascends to the dreaming spires of an exclusive college for young ladies, a very strict Victorian boarding school in Melbourne. Laura (Susannah Fowles) is strong willed and rebellious, which creates conflict with her peers and her teachers. In a desperate attempt to find acceptance with her peers, she weaves the most lurid yarns imaginable. The only real soulmate she finds is one of the senior girls. The novel by Henry Handel Richardson was published in 1910, and was so shocking at the time that the author’s name (Ethel Richardson) was stricken from the records of the school in which she set the thinly-disguised autobiography. An amusing and sometimes touching story which features an excellent performance from Barry Humphries as the repressed fire and brimstone minister. Also stars John Waters, Sheila Helpman, Patricia Kennedy and Julie Blake.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce Beresford, Phillip Adams, Australian Film Commission and Southern Cross Film Productions

results.title: Ka-wayawayama: Aeroplane Dance
results.creator_credit: Jan Wositzky, Trevor Graham, Christina Pozzan and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Records the story of “Ka-wayawayama” or “Aeroplane Dance” of the Yanuwa people of the Borroloola area in the Northern Territory. The dance was created after an American “Liberator” bomber crashed in the area in 1942, after a mission in the South-west Pacific. Re-creates the plight of the flight crew in their trek across inhospitable terrain across the Gulf of Carpentaria and the search for the lost crew.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jan Wositzky, Trevor Graham, Christina Pozzan and Film Australia

results.title: On our selection
results.creator_credit: Ken G. Hall, Bert Bailey and Bailey Film Productions
results.brief_description: The first Dad and Dave ‘talkie’ based on the long running stage hit that was derived from the stories of Steele Rudd. The play was a huge success with Depression audiences and in his screen adaptation, Ken Hall stressed the characters’ abilities to fight back against adversity. An early Australian classic.

results.title: Blackfellas
results.creator_credit: James Ricketson, Penny Chapman, David Rapsey and Barron Films
results.brief_description: But we’re your people. Doug Dooligan has lost count of the number of times he’s heard that phrase. Nineteen years old and on parole all he wants to do is get on with his life, away from the influence of his best friend Floyd “Pretty Boy” Davies. Doug wants to get a job, save some money and buy back his father’s property, Yetticup, the land of his people’s Dreaming. Floyd wants his old partner in crime to join him in “bigger and better things”. Floyd thinks Doug’s decision to go straight means that he is giving up on his “blackfella” lifestyle and being a “whitefella”. Doug is half white and is torn between his love for Floyd and his family obligations. The pressures of friendship, family, identity and blackfella versus whitefella lifestyles, almost jeopardise Doug’s chances of achieving his dream. He goes back to his old ways, but unexpectedly the tables turn and it is Floyd who acts to save Doug’s dream, and give him hope for the future. BLACKFELLAS is based on the book “Day of the dog” by Archie Weller, a Perth writer who grew up with the Nyoongah people from the Perth area and James Ricketson, the writer/director of BLACKFELLAS, consulted extensively with the Nyoongah community during the development of the script. It is a moving and powerful study of Aboriginal society which is shown from an insider’s perspective, producing a sensitive and compassionate drama. Awards: Winner, Feature Film Category, Human Rights Awards, 1993; Western Australian Premier’s Literary Award, 1993; Nominated, Best Achievement in Direction and Best Performance by an Actor in a Leading Role, Australian Film Institute Awards, 1993; Winner, Best Screenplay Adapted from Another Source and Best Performance by an Actor in a Supporting Role, Australian Film Institute Awards, 1993
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Ricketson, Penny Chapman, David Rapsey and Barron Films

results.title: Large as life: an interview with Pat Thompson
results.creator_credit: Charlotte Seymour and Women's Program of the AFC
results.brief_description: Pat Thompson, one of Australia’s most dynamic and entertaining jazz singers, is interviewed about her life and the resumption of her career after an absence of 34 years.

results.title: Blinky Bill
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross and Yoram Gross Films
results.brief_description: Blinky Bill the Koala sets off to try and find his mother after their peaceful bush home is destroyed by loggers. He meets new friends and has many adventures along the way in this delightful animated film, based on Dorothy Wall’s classic story.

results.title: Manganinnie
results.creator_credit: Daphne Crooks, Ross Hamilton, Robert Hynard, John Honey, Gilda Baracchi and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Manganinnie, fleeing the Aboriginal genocide of 1830 in Tasmania, rescues a tiny lost white child. Together they find compassion, love and a bond that delivers them from desperation, loneliness and the terror of pursuit. Based on the novel by Beth Roberts with music by Peter Sculthorpe and a script by Ken Kelso.

results.title: Jedda
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel and Charles Chauvel Productions
results.brief_description: ‘Jedda’, Charles Chauvel’s last feature film and Australia’s first in colour, is the story of a teenage Aboriginal girl who has been raised by a white woman, and finds herself drawn to Marbuck, a full-blooded Aborigine who comes to the station for work. The film falls readily into two halves. The first details Jedda’s upbringing and her emotional turmoil as to her identity, which is solved by Jedda herself, when the call of her blood leads her into the physical and psychological world of her people. The second half of the film, photographed in spectacular Central Australian locations, concentrates on the tension of the chase in which Marbuck and Jedda are pursued by the men from Jedda’s station. Cast includes Ngarla Kunoth as Jedda, Robert Tudawali as Marbuck, Betty Suttor, Paul Reynall, George Simpson-Lytle, Tas Fitzer, Wason Byers, Willie Farrar, Margaret Dingle. Also available on DVD [319218].
